comment_pe: MT is like any other tool we use to increase productivity and ease our work. It is very useful with texts in technical, general, and non-specialist texts. However, post-editor must be very careful as the machine is not always consistent and sometimes the translation is irrelevant.

degree_name: Bachelor of Arts in English Language and Translation
curr_position: Employed full time in a translation agency
comment_pe: It may need more improvement to be more efficient so we can rely on it.

degree_name: Masters in Arabic Translation from Jamia Millia Islamia University
Master's Degree in Translation and Cultural Mediation + Postgraduate Degree in Specialised Translation (Technical & Scientific)
curr_position: Employed full time in a translation agency
comment_pe: I think MT post-editing is essential in many cases as it's time-saving (especially for repetitive and longer tasks) as long as output quality is worth it (the MT engine should be adequately trained with corpora)

degree_name: Postgraduate 1-year course on Specialized Translation ENG > IT
comment_pe: MTPE can be useful for repetitive jobs, but it remains a quite boring activity. I prefer it if used in combination with computer-assisted translation.

degree_name: Bachelor Degree in Translation and Interpreting + 2 years specialization degree in Technical and Scientific Translation
comment_pe: As a technical translator also working in the patent field, MT allows me to save time and focus on other aspects of the translation job. I cannot trust MT for specific terminology with no context or in case of omonyms.

degree_name: Master in Translation by Utrecht University
comment_pe: It can save a lot of time.

degree_name: Bachelor of International Communication by Hogeschool Zuyd Maastricht, Department of Translation and Interpreting
comment_pe: It often saves time which allows me to work faster, but it also limits creativity. So depending on the type of text it's really useful at times, but sometimes it's just not useful at all.

degree_name: Master in Writing, Editing and Mediating at the University of Groningen
comment_pe: It depends very much on the type of content. MT is very useful for technical, straightforward and/or simple texts. It can save a lot of time when translating content for IT and manuals, especially when the MT uses a project-specific glossary. It is much less useful for more creative texts such as marketing, or content with more complex sentences, as it tends to lose sight of the grammatical structure fairly quickly. Generally, MT can also be used as a quick translation tool for individual terms, even if the rest of the sentence is unusable; expressions tend to be translated too literally, though.

degree_name: Undergraduate degree in Translation Studies by Hacettepe University
comment_pe: For the language pair I work with, machine translation usually does not provide grammatically accurate or fluent translations. As a result, I personally think not using MT at all and translating from scratch is easier than post-editing machine translation, at least 50% of the time.

degree_name: Bachelor's Degree in Translation and Interpreting by Istanbul University
comment_pe: I like being part of the technological progress but still think that the translation work usually includes some form or level of creativity. At the moment, MT is not able to provide that creativity.

From a translator's point of view, post-editing is like re-translating fuzzy matched TM entries from a regular translation project. The skill set it requires is similar to that of translation/proofreading. The main difference is that a translator/proofreader needs to have deep knowledge of both the source and target language, while, depending on the content of the post-editing project it is sufficient for a post-editor to have strong knowledge of the target language and of the specific domain, with a working knowledge of the source language. Even though it may reduce the overall translation costs and thus my personal income, personally I find post-editing jobs enjoyable, since they require me to solve errors.

degree_name: Master in Translation by the Institute of Social Education
curr_position: Employed full time in a translation agency
comment_pe: МТ can be quite helpful in translation of simple technical texts, but as it's still far from being good in complex sentences and concepts, I don't use it very often.

degree_name: Master in Translation by the Kiev International University
curr_position: Employed full time in a translation agency
comment_pe: It's useful for technical texts and small phrases or lists but isn't suitable for marketing texts.

curr_position: Employed full time in a translation agency
comment_pe: Machine translation is simply the future of translation. It saves vast amounts of time and nowadays is a must-have option for big projects and repetitive work. It also helps a lot to maintain the consistence of translations.  But it is still required to check and post-edit the translations provided by neural networks, as they are not always accurate and sometimes do not convey the emotional sides of the text, and it also happens that they change the sense to the opposite. I also sometimes feel not comfortable because I realize that sometimes soon I may easily be replaced by a computer at my workplace and will have to look for another job. But that is what progress is, so I must get along with that.

degree_name: Master in Translation Hanoi University of Science and Technology
curr_position: Employed full time in a translation agency
comment_pe: Post-editing machine translation sometimes helps save time. It can be used for simple and repetitive content. However, for creative ones, using post-editing machine translation can make me less creative.

degree_name: Bachelor in Translation by Translation by Hanoi University of Science and Technology
curr_position: Employed full time in a translation agency
comment_pe: I like using MT to check certain words and expressions or to have a general understanding of the topics only. I don't like machine translation. Directly comparing the source and MT, to some extent, limits my in-depth thinking and word choice in a specific context.

degree_name: Master in Translation by the University of XYZ.
comment_pe: Machine translation can be very helpful in some cases when the source content is repetitive and/or has simple and straightforward structures and expressions, etc. In such cases, machine translated content can be pretty accurate and post-editing work can be done faster than translating from scratch. When the source content is more of creative type or uses idiomatic/stylistic expressions, etc., MT often produces too literal targets and loses the style and subtle nuances of the source. Besides, working on post-editing MT too often may affect the creativity of translators as the brain are used to being given content to modify instead of creating its own translation. However, in some cases, MT can provide great ideas for specific words and expressions since the data used to feed algorithms comes from various minds around the world.
